Award.AwardTitle: Quantitative Studies of Intrinsically Disordered Protein Structure and Function

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this research project broad principles wil be developed to describe the structure of highly flexible proteins, which will provide predictive insight into their function. The PI's new models connecting molecular structure and function for highly flexible proteins will lead to the routine quantitative characterization of these molecular systems. A new experimental methodology will be implemented for atomic resolution characterization of the structures possessed by highly flexible proteins and the changes to those structures that often accompany binding to other macromolecules. As a result, this research and associated training activities will yield fundamental, molecular level insights into essential biological processes that will benefit the biotechnology industry. This program will train junior scientists to seek fundamental insight into the systems and processes from biochemistry, using the principles and quantitative laws from the physical sciences. During each year of the project, the PI will bring middle school students from disadvantaged backgrounds to Penn State University in order to illustrate for them the opportunities that arise from higher education in science and engineering fields. Additionally, the PI has been named a mentor for two Penn State programs that aim to bring under-represented minority undergraduate students into the research laboratory. Through these programs, the PI will bring a minimum of one enrolled student per year of the project into his laboratory. Trainees supported by this project will continue to provide the daily mentorship of all students engaging in these outreach programs, with guidance from the PI, who is firmly committed to expanding opportunities in science for students from diverse backgrounds.

The research objective of this project is to quantitatively describe intrinsically disordered protein (IDP) ensembles and structure-function relationships on the atomic and molecular scale. The challenge is to find a model that best describes the conformational features of highly flexible biomolecules, as this structural description is intimately connected with cellular function. From a broader point of view, the objective is to develop new models for protein conformation and dynamics that lead to the application of structural biological tools to IDPs, which are hypothesized to possess native structure that is directly responsible for imparting their specific functions. Defining structure-function relationships for IDPs requires broadening the traditionally narrow paradigm developed for cooperatively folding systems. This project continues efforts to develop quantitative and efficient tools for experimentally constraining IDP structure and site-specific interactions with other biomolecules through carbon-detected NMR spectroscopy. Traditionally acquired (i.e., 1H-detected) NMR spectra of IDPs suffer from poor chemical shift dispersion, rendering them unsuitable to high resolution applications in most cases. It has been shown that 13C-direct detection spectroscopy generally produces spectra suitable for quantitative analysis of IDPs. The development of carbon-detected NMR methods for the study of IDPs will continue to be developed during the course of this project. Recently a fully atomistic structural ensemble of the protein FCP1 in its unbound state has been resolved. This project will expand efforts to include structural characterization of the complex formed between FCP1 and its folded partner Rap74, while also defining the conformational ensemble of a segment from the RNA Polymerase II C-terminal domain, which is the biological target of the FCP1 phosphatase activity. Finally, it is necessary to connect structural findings to functional outcomes. For the model systems investigated in this project, biological function can be assayed by defining binding interactions between the IDPs under study and their cooperatively folded partners. Functional hypothesis testing will be primarily carried out through quantitative calorimetric binding studies, establishing the energetic consequences of intrinsic disorder and defining the driving forces for disordered protein interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A large fraction of the proteins found in cells do not adopt a single, persistent structure, but instead remain highly disordered. This observation is one of the most exciting changes to the field of protein biochemistry to have emerged in the past twenty years. The research objective of this project was to contribute broad principles that could quantitatively describe intrinsically disordered protein (IDP) ensembles, leading to predictive insight into how these proteins function. From a technological point of view, our objective was to develop new experimental approaches to define protein conformation and dynamics, leading to the application of structural biological tools to IDPs, which we hypothesize do possess native structure that is directly responsible for imparting their specific functions, even if that structure is very different from what biochemists have been classically trained to expect.

Our first major accomplishment was to generate representations of the structure for three separate proteins that simultaneously captured both high-resolution, atomic-level detail, and also lower resolution molecular detail. This has been especially challenging for disordered proteins because it requires simultaneous constraint of structure across a wide range of length scales that is generally too great for any single experimental technique when the protein being analyzed is highly flexible. The breadth of this accomplishment was significant because our three protein targets were selected for their diverse amino acid compositions and therefore the breadth of conformational preferences their structures were likely to display. In this way, we were able to provide insight into the tendency of some disordered proteins to adopt helical structures, yet with lower stability than in fully folded systems. Similarly, we gained insight into the effects of the amino acid proline on disordered protein structures, which is significant because this amino acid is abundant in disordered systems and has very unique properties compared with the other natural amino acids.

Our second major accomplishment is a very exciting example of the influence proline can have on disordered protein structure. One of the most important ways that signals are transferred in cells is through chemical modification of existing proteins, which can alter their functions. Specifically, phosphorylation of serine residues in proteins is often used to activate or inactivate molecular processes. The protein RNA Polymerase II, which is responsible for creating the preliminary copies of genes needed to produce new proteins, is subject to extensive and reversible serine phosphorylation. We showed that in certain sequence contexts, phosphorylation of serine-proline pairs causes a structural rearrangement in the proline (trans-to-cis isomerization) that is a significant enough change for downstream enzymes to read. This novel regulatory mechanism may be common in disordered proteins and we intend to test this premise moving forward.

Finally, we were able to make the major biochemical and biophysical observations described above because we have invested significant effort to develop new approaches in nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. With NSF support, we have worked for the past decade to develop new NMR detection strategies that make it possible to observe structure in a wide range of disordered protein systems, which have traditionally been very hard to access by NMR. In order to maximize the impact of our research, the software required for other investigators to implement our new experimental techniques is always distributed through the Penn State ScholarSphere. This initiative provides stable, open-access archiving of our results for use by any investigator.

This project involved two postdoctoral scientists, plus multiple graduate students and undergraduate students. The environment in which this project was carried out benefited from our laboratory?s participation in the Penn State Center for Eukaryotic Gene Regulation, which provided a rich and interdisciplinary training environment for all project participants. Particular emphasis was placed on the involvement of women and underrepresented minorities with the goal of increasing their participation in science and related professional disciplines.
